lines.line: 7:00 AM, June 20th, District Court House #3
(You can do this, Perl!)
(It's like riding a bike ... right?)
My name is Perl. I'm a junior attorney with the Prime & Co Law Office.
While I've had a lot of minor cases this past year, I've never had something quite like this ...
I just know that I'm ready, though!
... who am I talking to?
... where's my client?
Maybe I'm not as ready as I thought ...
Oh!
Good evening.
Evening ... isn't it morning?
It's always evening here.
In the halls of justice ... didn't you know?
Err ... no. I didn't. Look, I'll be honest with you ...
Your case is looking pretty rough.
. . . I'm waiting for my attorney. I don't want to talk about it.
I -am- your attorney.
We met just yesterday, remember?
(Yikes . . .)
You're always my attorney here.
In the halls of justice ... didn't you know?
That sounded better in my head.
I didn't get much sleep last night . . .
(I'm doomed.)
Let's just focus on the case.
Can you tell me what happened, again?
There's not much to tell.
I went to his house that night. He called me over.
I hadn't heard from the guy in years.
We're old pals, you know. We went way back . . .
Look, don't worry about it.
I'm sure you're innocent. You'll come through okay!
I'm always innocent ...
That's it. You were expecting more? I'm always innocent, and this time is no exception.
I promise.
That's all I need to hear. I promise that you'll be found innocent!
(I hope I can keep that promise . . .)
So that's my client, Java. He's in some sort of programming job, and he was friends with the victim.
I don't know him all that well yet, but I get the feeling he's hiding something ...
... who are you talking to?
I'm so sorry! I, umm ... I think I hear the bailiff calling us right now!
Really? It doesn't look like it's time yet . . .
Nopeit'sdefinitelytimelet'sgo!
7:30 AM, June 20th, Court Room, District Court House #3
(The judge doesn't look too pleased ...)
Don't worry about it.
You look nervous.
Me? Nervous? Not at all! I don't understand what you mean!
It's no problem.
If I'm found guilty . . .
I probably deserve it.
. . . what do you mean?
It's a long story. You probably don't want to hear it.
But -
Court is now in session for the trial of Java Script.
Defense, are you ready?
R--ready, your Honor. The Defense is ready.
Very good. Prosecution, are you ready?
The Prosecution is ready, your Honor.
You -- !
(I didn't expect to see Christian here . . .)
. . . more ready than the Defense is, it would seem.
Defense, is there a problem?
No! I mean ... no, your Honor.
I'm just ...
Really certain my client is innocent!
Yes, that's what the trial is for.
Determing innocence.
R - right.
. . . Prosecutor, your opening statement.
Certainly, your Honor.
The victim is Bracket, a 32 year old male.
He works for a local web development agency. His rivalry with Java is well known in the community.
He was found murdered in his office a little after 6 am.
His computer was on, with Java's latest project on it -- I'm afraid we don't have the details yet.
The house butler found the scene and called the police.
Police went to arrest Java and found him at his place of work.
Java admits he went to the victim's house that night.
So as you see, he's clearly guilty.
Indeed.
Wait, what?
I find the defendant --
Hold it!
We haven't even gone through with the trial yet!
We haven't?
No! I haven't even had my chance to speak!
You haven't?
No!
Oh ... well then, what do you want to do?
(What do I want to do?)
The defense would like to call the arresting officer to the stand!
(If I'm going to prove his innocence, I need to hear more details.)
As you wish. It isn't going to get you very far, I warn you.
Bailiff! Please escort the arresting officer inside.
8:00 AM, June 20th, Court Room, District Court House #3
Witness, please state your name for the record.
Linter, sir! It's Detective Linter!
With less enthusiasm.
Err ... Detective Linter, sir.
And you arrested Java on the night of the murder?
That's right, sir! I got 'em good! We made that arrest right that very morning!
And we're all very proud.
(What a goofball . . .)
Could you speak more about that morning?
Of course I can! Are you doubting me?
Well, no, but --
Psh! Lawyers!
Am I right?
We all know he's guilty, pal!
(This is off to a bad start ...)
Don't you think we should be thorough? That's good police work.
Hmm ... yeah! Thorough!
Alright, sure!
But you'd better not try any of your lawyer tricks!
(Wouldn't dream of it.)
Just proceed, Detective.
Absolutely, sir!
Why He's Guilty
Yeah, we went and arrested Java.
He was there the night of the murder. He admits it himself!
The butler called us up and we got there immediately.
After looking at the body, it could only be Java!
He smashed Bracket in the head. *WHAM*!
(Now it's looking even worse.)
Well? Are we done with this charade?
I don't think so.
I have a right to cross-examine this witness!
Of course you do.
But you won't find anything.
(He's hiding something ... and I'm going to find out what!)
Why He's Guilty
Yeah, we went and arrested Java.
On what grounds?
On what grounds? Pal, I'd be here all day if I listed 'em!
Just listen up! Let me finish first!
What the heck is that?
Try again.
He was there the night of the murder. He admits it himself!
Why was he there that night?
What, he didn't tell you either?
He said he was there for a visit ... and he wouldn't tell us anything else.
That's pretty damning if you ask me!
What the heck is that?
Try again.
The butler called us up and we got there immediately.
How long did it take you to arrive at the scene?
Oh, not long at all. About five minutes!
That's pretty fast ...
Best in the state! No doubt!
But, err ... the victim died much earlier, I'm afraid.
(He died earlier?)
What the heck is that?
Try again.
After looking at the body, it could only be Java!
What did you discover after examining the body?
Oh, uhh ... lots of stuff ...
(Lots of stuff ...? Should I press him harder?)
What do you mean, stuff?!
That's rather vague, Detective.
Well, uhh ... we did an autopsy ...
An autopsy! Why wasn't this submitted to the court record?
Mr. Sharp told me not to mention it ... sorry.
I need to see that autopsy, your Honor!
Of course. Prosecutor Sharp, please submit this autopsy to the court immediately.
Y--yes, your Honor.
I just didn't want to confuse the defense with un-necessary information.
Autopsy report added to the court record.
Oh ... well, alright then. Continue, witness.
Right. As I was saying, pal ...
What the heck is that?
Try again.
He smashed Bracket in the head. *WHAM*!
What was the victim struck with?
A teacup. Java's fingerprints were on it, pal.
A teacup?
I know, right?
A teacup to the back of the head. What a way to go ...
When I go out, I hope someone at least hits me with a good beverage -- like an espresso, maybe.
(Hmmn . . . do I have anything that contradicts his testimony?)
What the heck is that?
Try again.
Detective ... according to you, the victim died from a blow to the back of the head, correct?
Yeah. What about it, pal? I said no lawyer tricks!
Oh, I'm not tricking anyone detective.
The person tricking us is you, Prosecutor Sharp!
M -- me?
I haven't done anything of the sort!
On the contrary.
You hid the autopsy report on purpose!
You knew that it would be bad for you if it got out!
The teacup cannot possibly be the murder weapon.
It can't?! Why not?
Hang on . . . the Defense is . . . babbling nonsense.
Prosecutor Sharp isn't quite in the dark as you, Detective.
It's simple, really.
Have you ever seen someone stabbed with a teacup?
Stabbed with a teacup?
According to this autopsy report, the victim's cause of death was likely a stabbing.
Not a blow to the head!
Nngh!
So as you can see, the prosecution is wasting everyone's time.
So it would seem.
What do you have to say for yourself, Prosecutor Sharp?
I apologize, your Honor . . .
I was just hoping to save us all time.
Save us time?
Indeed. You see, the Prosecution still contends that Java is guilty.
He is?
You do?
Of course. That's my job you know, rooting out the guilty.
I would be terrible at my job if I relied on flimsy evidence like that teacup.
Speaking of which, let me add that to the court record now. Don't want to make that mistake again.
Shattered Teacup added to the court record.
I thought that whole charade would be a good warmup for the Defense, naturally.
To make sure they were reading the court record.
(Liar! You didn't even submit the report!)
Detective, please explain why you -really- arrested Java.
Right away, sir!
(Sharp thinks he's so clever ... but I'll find the contradiction in this testimony, too!)
Proof?
Oh, we have proof alright!
I was just joking before.
The real murder weapon was a knife! His fingerprints are all over it!
They were having evening tea when . . .
Java stabbed his friend and then ran for it!
F -- fingerprints?!
Yes, you're aware of what fingerprints are, I hope?
Of course I know what fingerprints are!
Then surely you cannot think your client is innocent!
(My client . . .)
(What should I do . . .?)
There is no need to prolong this trial.
Perl.
I didn't do it.
I know, but . . .
I didn't do it. It's as simple as that.
So nothing has changed. You have to find the truth, right? Just like I find bugs.
Right . . .
There's a bug in his testimony somewhere. I trust you to sniff it out.
You're right!
I'm rooting for you.
I find the defendant, Java Script . . .
Objection!
Your Honor, please!
Let me cross-examine this witness!
You have nothing to gain by doing that! The Defense is stalling for time!
. . . well, it is almost lunch time . . .
It won't take long! I have an idea!
(No I don't.)
No you don't.
I do! And I'll prove it right now!
(I hope.)
You may proceed, Defense.
Proof?
Oh, we have proof alright!
Where is your proof?!
Hold on, pal! I'm about to tell you!
Take a look at this, your Honor!
. . . what is it? I don't get it . . .
Err . . . it's proof that . . . the defendant . . .
I will take a moment to remind you not to flippantly object, Defense.
Urgh!
I was just joking before.
Why would you joke about a thing like that?!
Well, not a joke . . . maybe more like a ploy?
Detective! It is a crime to lie on the stand!
Sorry, sorry!
(Sheesh . . .)
Take a look at this, your Honor!
. . . what is it? I don't get it . . .
Err . . . it's proof that . . . the defendant . . .
I will take a moment to remind you not to flippantly object, Defense.
Urgh!
The real murder weapon was a knife!
Do you have this knife here?
Of course. And you can look at it all you want too, pal!
You aren't gonna find anything!
Knife added to the court record.
Take a look at this, your Honor!
. . . what is it? I don't get it . . .
Err . . . it's proof that . . . the defendant . . .
I will take a moment to remind you not to flippantly object, Defense.
Urgh!
They were having evening tea when . . .
(What should I ask about . . .?)
What time did the two of them take their tea?
They had tea around 8:00pm. It was just the two of them.
(8:00pm? That leaves a pretty large window . . .)
Anyways . . .
Can you tell me anything about the tea or the teacup?
Well ... it's tea.
You'd have to ask the butler -- butlers know about that sort of stuff, right?
What I can tell you is that the teacup is Bracket's. The butler confirmed that much.
(Hmmn ... )
Could you tell me more about the victim and defendant's relationship?
Well sure, pal.
Java and Bracket went to the same school together. Both graduated top of their class.
Both applied to the same jobs, too. They've had a rivalry ever since.
For details you should ask Bracket's wife. She'd know more.
(Bracket has a wife?)
Take a look at this, your Honor!
. . . what is it? I don't get it . . .
Err . . . it's proof that . . . the defendant . . .
I will take a moment to remind you not to flippantly object, Defense.
Urgh!
Java stabbed his friend and then ran for it!
So do you think the murder was premeditated?
Unlikely, pal. You don't leave a dead body lyin' around if you planned it ahead of time.
My thinking is they got in an argument that just went ugly. It happens.
Take a look at this, your Honor!
. . . what is it? I don't get it . . .
Err . . . it's proof that . . . the defendant . . .
I will take a moment to remind you not to flippantly object, Defense.
Urgh!
(I can't find anything wrong in this testimony!)
(But I can't give up yet!)
Is something wrong, Defense?
No, your Honor, I just . . .
Do you have an objection to this witness' testimony?
Well . . .
Of course she doesn't, your Honor.
This case is already settled.
In that case, I find the defendant . . .
Objection!
I don't want to talk about it, but . . .
But I have no choice now! I will confess!
Confess?!
I'll . . . confess what we were doing on that dark, stormy night.
Our words like swords, clashing against one another . . .
(Maybe not the best choice of words . . .)
Your Honour, let me take the stand!
Hmmn . . .
This is ridiculous! We were about to make a decision.
A confession doesn't change anything.
The defendant deserves to be heard, your Honour!
(I'm not sure where I'm going with this, but . . . it can't possibly get worse!)
. . . I suppose I can allow it. Justice should be thorough.
We will take a five minute recess, and then court will resume.
Thank you for playing my game!
Story development is unfortunately unfinished at the moment.
But don't worry!
I fully intend to finish writing this story. Check back again sometime!
